{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2016}} {{About|Norman Rockwell's fictional character|the television character|The Rookies|the American football player|Willie Gillus}} {{multiple image | align = right | image1 = Willie Gillis Food Package.jpg|width1 =158 | image2 = Willie Gillis Home on Leave.JPG|width2 = 156 | caption1 = The Willie Gillis debut: ''Willie Gillis Food Package'' (1941-10-04) | caption2 = ''Willie Gillis Home on Leave'' (1941-11-29) | footer_align = center | footer =
Willie Gillis series
[[Norman Rockwell]]
[[The Saturday Evening Post]] }} '''Willie Gillis, Jr.''' (more commonly simply '''Willie Gillis''') is a fictional character created by [[Norman Rockwell]] for a series of [[World War II]] paintings that appeared on the covers of eleven issues of ''[[The Saturday Evening Post]]'' between 1941 and 1946.{{cite press release|url=http://www.philadelphiahistory.org/akm/press/photo/?action=viewPressRelease&id=e37709b0b7b228315ffd0c71ec17c9c3|title=NORMAN ROCKWELL'S WARTIME COVERS|accessdate=April 4, 2008|publisher=Atwater Kent Museum of Philadelphia}} With the rank of [[Private (rank)|private]],{{cite web|url=http://www.jdnews.com/articles/gillis_7990___article.html/cover_dick.html|title=�Willie Gillis’ makes a return visit to the USO|accessdate=April 4, 2008|publisher=Freedom Communications, Inc.|date=April 11, 2006|work=jdnews.com}} Gillis was an [[everyman]] whose career was tracked on the cover of the ''Post'' from induction through discharge without being depicted in [[battle]]. Gillis and his girlfriend were modeled by two of Rockwell's acquaintances. Although Gillis was not exclusively used on ''Post'' covers, the Willie Gillis series of covers was a hallmark of Rockwell's wartime work. In Rockwell's prime and at the peak of its popularity, the ''Post'' had a subscribership of 4 million, and many of these subscribers believed Gillis was a real person. Rockwell's wartime art, including Willie Gillis, the ''[[Four Freedoms (Norman Rockwell)|Four Freedoms]]'' and ''[[Rosie the Riveter]]'', contributed to the success of the [[war bond|wartime bond]] sales efforts. Since 1999 the Gillis series has been included in two major Rockwell tours. From 1999 to 2002 it toured as part of a Rockwell ''Post'' [[cover art]] retrospective, and from 2006 to 2010 it toured as part of a 1940s World War II Rockwell art exhibition. == Background == From 1916 through his [[John F. Kennedy]] memorial cover on December 16, 1963, Rockwell created 321 magazine [[Book cover|covers]] for the ''Post'',{{cite web|url=http://www.tfaoi.com/newsm1/n1m369.htm|title=Cover Story -- Norman Rockwell's America|accessdate=April 4, 2008|date=July 4, 2003|publisher=Traditional Fine Art Online, Inc.}} which was the most popular American magazine of the first half of the 20th century with a subscribership that reached a peak of 4 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.tfaoi.com/aa/1aa/1aa103.htm|title=Norman Rockwell: Pictures for the American People|accessdate=April 7, 2008|publisher=Traditional Fine Art Online, Inc/[[High Art Museum]]}} Rockwell illustrated [[Culture of the United States|American life]] during [[World War I]] and [[World War II]] in 34 of his cover illustrations, and he illustrated 33 ''Post'' covers in total during World War II. Some of the war art involved American life. During much of the first half of the 1940s, Rockwell's cover illustrations focused on the human side of the war. Rockwell encouraged support of the war efforts during World War II by means of his covers, that endorsed [[war bond]]s, encouraged women to work, and encouraged men to enlist in the service. His World War II illustrations used themes of patriotism, longing, shifting gender roles, reunion, love, work, community and family during wartime to promote the war. In his role as a magazine illustrator during times of war, Rockwell draws comparisons to [[Winslow Homer]], an [[American Civil War]] illustrator for ''[[Harper's Weekly]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.yale.edu/ynhti/curriculum/units/2004/3/04.03.01.x.html|title=American Genre Painting in the Nineteenth Century: Teaching Artistic Interpretation as a Tool for Critically Viewing History|accessdate=April 5, 2008|publisher=the Yale-New Haven Teachers Institute|author=Boucher, Justin M.}} Rockwell's artistic expressions were said to have helped the adoption of the goal of the [[Four Freedoms]] as set forth by [[United States President]] [[Franklin Roosevelt]]'s 1941 [[State of the Union Address]].{{cite web|url=http://www.spartacus.schoolnet.co.uk/USAsaturday.htm|title=Saturday Evening Post|accessdate=April 5, 2008}} His painting series, the ''[[Four Freedoms (Norman Rockwell)|Four Freedoms]]'', toured in a war bond effort that raised [[United States dollar|$]]132 million.{{cite press release|url=http://www.michenermuseum.org/press/?item=2007-08-08|title=Michener Art Museum Pairs Famed American Illustrators Rockwell and Hargens for Fall Exhibitions in New Hope|publisher=The James A. Michener Art Museum|accessdate=April 5, 2008|date=August 8, 2007}} Willie Gillis was a [[freckle]]-faced [[All-American]] character who served as one of Rockwell's main coverboys during World War II.{{cite web|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:ORLB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0EB4F02EECD895D3&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Soldier's Story is Story of War|accessdate=January 10, 2009|date=February 2, 1992|publisher=[[Newsbank]]|work=[[The Orlando Sentinel]]|author=Mckeen, William}} The Gillis character is widely referred to as an everyman who epitomized the typical American World War II Soldier.{{cite web|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:BNHB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=10264887B7CDF4FD&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Rockwell museum celebrates the vision of the man who put America on canvas |accessdate=January 10, 2009|date=May 3, 1992|publisher=[[Newsbank]]|work=[[Boston Herald]]|author=Jenks, Homer}}{{cite web|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:WPIW&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0EB284096B17FBC6&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Norman Rockwell, American Master (Seriously)|accessdate=January 10, 2009|date=June 6, 1993|publisher=[[Newsbank]]|work=[[Washington Post]]|author=Richard, Paul}}{{cite web|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:WSTB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0EB08BF25D6ACCF6&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Chasing summer's hottest hits - Exhibits that have become crowd-pleasers|accessdate=January 10, 2009|date=June 29, 2000|publisher=[[Newsbank]]|work=[[Washington Times]]|author=Rauschart, Lisa}} Rockwell created Gillis in 1940 as the [[European Theatre of World War II]] was escalating and Americans were enlisting or being drafted under the [[Selective Training and Service Act of 1940]] in the armed forces. Rockwell credits the name Willie Gillis to his wife,{{cite book|title=Norman Rockwell Illustrator|isbn=0-07-025213-0|publisher=Watson-Guptill Publications|pages=182–3|year=1946|author=Guptill, Arthur L.}} who derived it from an old children's book, ''[[Wee Willie Winkie]]''. Rockwell described Gillis as "an inoffensive, ordinary little guy thrown into the chaos of war." The public identified with Rockwell's portrayal of the "little guy" living up to a sense of duty in this time of war.{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/features/2001/0110.larson.html|title=Reconstructing Rockwell: How an American icon became an artist|accessdate=April 5, 2008|date=October 2001|author=Larson, Christina|publisher= The Washington Monthly}} Gillis was truly seen as the typical [[GI (military)|G.I.]],{{cite news|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9806E5D91E3CF937A25753C1A9679C8B63|title= ART/ARCHITECTURE; Salve for a Wounded People|accessdate=April 7, 2008|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=October 14, 2001|author=Marling, Karal Ann}} and Rockwell's wartime art remains quite popular: his signed original May 29, 1943 depiction of ''[[Rosie the Riveter]]'' sold at a [[Sotheby's]] auction on May 22, 2002 for $4,959,500.{{cite web|url=http://www.rosietheriveter.org/painting.htm|title=Rockwell's Rosie the Riveter Painting Auctioned|accessdate=April 5, 2008}} Some of the Willie Gillis paintings and the ''Rosie the Riveter'' painting were [[raffle]]d off during the [[United States Department of the Treasury]]'s Second War Loan Drive, which ran from April 12 – May 1, 1943.{{cite web|url=http://library.duke.edu/digitalcollections/adaccess/warbonds.html#second|title=Brief History of World War Two Advertising Campaigns War Loans and Bonds|accessdate=January 10, 2009|date=August 7, 2008|publisher=[[Duke University]] Libraries|work=Digital Collections}} The Gillis character endures generations later for literary and artistic comparison. == Post Illustrations == [[File:Willie Gillis in Convoy.jpg|thumb|''Willie Gillis in Convoy'' (1943) was a depiction of Gillis close to the battlefield that was not used as cover art.]] [[File:Willie Gillis in College.jpg|thumb|''Willie Gillis in College'' (1946-10-05) broke with the style of the wartime posters, depicting Gillis as a civilian in a peaceful environment.]] === Series review === In ''Willie Gillis: Food Package'', Gillis' 1941, he toted a [[care package]]. Ten subsequent covers depicted Gillis in a variety of roles: at church in uniform, holding his hat on his lap; soldier on K.P. duty; the son carrying on the family tradition of military service; a still life of Gillis' family photographs; and two fighting mad girls, holding pictures of Gillis that he'd sent each of them from the war zone. Gillis matured over the course of the series until he was almost unrecognizable in the final work.{{cite web|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:AMCB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=11D1FA2E73F6CF88&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Tribute in Bucks to all-American storytellers Rockwell , Hargens |accessdate=January 10, 2009|date=November 22, 2007|publisher=[[Newsbank]]|work=[[The Morning Call]]|author=Gehman, Geoff}} Rockwell created a good ending for the series by depicting Gillis relaxing while studying at college on the [[G.I. Bill]]: "We know that things ended well for Gillis, though; his final cover in 1946 showed the young man stretched in a windowsill smoking a pipe and wearing penny loafers, studying at Middlebury College." To some, the fourth piece – ''Willie Gillis: Hometown News'' – was the one that cemented Willie Gillis' place in American history, because families identified with Gillis.{{cite web|url=http://www.quinnpublishing.net/untitled_folder/rockwell.html|title=Norman Rockwell: A Star on Our Flag|accessdate=April 5, 2008|author=Cutler, Judy A. G.}} The sixth piece, ''Willie Gillis in Church'', is the earliest of his works with significant religious themes.{{cite web|url=http://www.listten.com/article.cfm?id=8|title=Norman Rockwell and the Church of Your Choice|accessdate=April 5, 2008|publisher=Mark Coppenger|author=Coppenger, Mark|year=2000}} This final component of the series, ''Willie Gillis in College'', engenders much critical review because it is perceived to represent a transformation of character.{{cite journal |last= Clark |first= Daniel A. |authorlink= |coauthors= |year= 1998|month= |title="The Two Joes Meet. Joe College, Joe Veteran": the G. I. Bill, College Education, and Postwar American Culture |journal=History of Education Quarterly |volume=38 |issue=2 (Summer, 1998) |pages=165–189 |id= |quote=|doi=10.2307/369985 |jstor= 369985 |publisher= History of Education Society }} It is owned by the [[Washington Mutual]] Bank of [[Seattle]]. In 2000, they loaned it to the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]].{{cite web|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:WISB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0EAEFDE2A454690A&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Japanese Lantern Fest Today|accessdate=January 10, 2009|date=May 5, 2000|publisher=[[Newsbank]]|work=[[Wisconsin State Journal]]}} It is a study in contrast of mood and style from the wartime components of the series. Throughout the cover series Gillis was never pictured in battle or in any sort of danger, armed or with armed foes because Rockwell felt those portrayals were better exhibited by [[newsreel]]s and [[photograph]]s.{{cite web|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:PHIB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0EB5CE9279A457EF&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Museum Has Beloved Artist Covered All 31 Covers Norman Rockwell Did for the Saturday Evening Post Are on Display at the Atwater Kent Museum|accessdate=January 10, 2009|date=August 19, 1999|publisher=[[Newsbank]]|work=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|author= Keating, Douglas J.}}{{cite web|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:CHCB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0FD87F55CDB41B1E&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Images of America|accessdate=January 10, 2009|date=July 2, 1999|publisher=[[Newsbank]]|work=[[Courier-Post]]|author=Matheson, Kathy}} Rockwell produced at least one depiction of Gillis that was not on the cover. The painting ''Willie Gillis in Convoy'' was produced in 1943, depicting Gillis, in combat gear, in the back of a covered military vehicle with his rifle in hand. Rockwell donated the painting to the [[Gardner High School]] for the graduating class, where it hung in the [[principal (school)|principal]]'s office until 2000. The school then loaned it to the [[Gardner Museum]]. A charcoal [[Sketch (drawing)|sketch]] of the painting sold for $107,000 in 1999.{{cite web|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:WTLB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0EADE55BD505C5E4&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Gardner to Show Its Rockwell|accessdate=January 10, 2009|date=June 16, 2000|publisher=[[Newsbank]]|work=[[Worcester Telegram & Gazette]]|author=Hill, Mary Jo}} There was concern that the painting was not hung in a secure location. In 2005, the painting was [[Art conservation and restoration|restored]] and rehung at the high school.{{cite web|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:WTLB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=10A381B8D0BB5D4F&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=On view: original Rockwell|accessdate=January 10, 2009|date=May 19, 2005|publisher=[[Newsbank]]|work=[[Worcester Telegram & Gazette]]|author=Barnes, George}} === Models === Robert Otis "Bob" Buck served as Rockwell's model for Gillis and eventually enlisted for service in the [[United States Navy]].{{cite web|url=http://www.best-norman-rockwell-art.com/norman-rockwell-magazine-cover-list-1940-1980.html|title=Norman Rockwell Magazine Covers Complete List - Part Six: 1940 to 1980|accessdate=April 4, 2008|publisher=Best Norman Rockwell Art.com}} Buck's job in Arlington was as a [[sawmill]] hand.Murray and McCabe, p. 11. When the 15-year-old Buck met Rockwell to pose for the first time, Buck only stood {{convert|5|ft|4|in|m}} tall.{{cite web|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:SUNB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0FA12EFAD00CEFEC&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Rockwell 's GI model at Big E|accessdate=January 10, 2009|date=September 29, 2002|publisher=[[Newsbank]]|work=[[The Republican (Springfield)|The Republican]]|author=Barry, Stephanie}} At that time, Buck had a lock of hair that used to drop down on his forehead. Rockwell had been seeking a model, and met Buck at a [[square dance]] in [[Arlington, Vermont]]. Rockwell observed Buck from different angles during the dance, and Buck told Rockwell that if he did not stop staring, Buck would knock him flat. Buck had been exempted from the [[military draft]], but he felt serving his country was his patriotic duty and enlisted as a [[naval aviation|naval aviator]] in 1943.{{cite book|title=Norman Rockwell's World War II: Impressions From the Homefront|publisher=United Services|author=Meyer, Susan E.|year=1991|isbn=0-9631011-0-2}} cited at {{cite web|url=http://fineart.ha.com/common/view_item.php?Sale_No=677&Lot_No=58377|title=2007 December Illustration Art Signature Auction #677|accessdate=April 4, 2008|publisher=Heritage Auctions, Inc.}} Buck served in the [[South Sea Islands|South Seas]] during the war. Once Buck enlisted, Rockwell worked from memory and photographs to complete his illustrations, and sometimes he only worked Gillis into the background via a photograph on the wall. Rockwell was going to discontinue the series, but ''Post'' editors objected because his character was too popular.{{cite book|title=My Adventures as an Illustrator: Norman Rockwell|publisher=Harry N. Abrams|author=Rockwell, Norman|origyear=1960|year=1995|isbn=0-8109-2596-6}} cited at {{cite web|url=http://fineart.ha.com/common/view_item.php?Sale_No=677&Lot_No=58377|title=2007 December Illustration Art Signature Auction #677|accessdate=April 4, 2008|publisher=Heritage Auctions, Inc.}} The public enjoyed closely scrutinizing Gillis' affairs.{{cite web|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:SUNB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=108778E8B00857A7&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Rockwell 's popular 'Post' covers shown|accessdate=January 10, 2009|date=December 23, 2004|publisher=[[Newsbank]]|work=[[The Republican (Springfield)|The Republican]]|author=O'Connor, Keith J.}} Gillis was so popular that at one point, the ''Post'' was receiving hundreds of letter inquiring about the tribulations of the character who was perceived by many as real, and concern for the private was particularly high among families named Gillis. Although Buck had departed, the model who portrayed Gillis' girlfriend (fellow ''Post'' illustrator Mead Schaeffer's daughter) remained available, so Rockwell painted her faithfully sleeping at midnight on [[New Year's Eve]] with photos of Willie Gillis in the background above her bed in ''Willie Gillis: New Year's Eve''. The subsequent {{convert|11|in|mm}} × {{convert|14|in|mm}} Willie Gillis cover, ''Willie Gillis: Generations'', depicting the Gillis military family in pictures above a bookshelf of Gillis war books, generated hundreds of letters from Gillises, many of whom wanted to buy the imaginary books. Mead's daughters Lee and Patty Schaeffer showed vying affections for Gillis in one ''Post'' cover.Murray and McCabe, p. 16. == Modern references == The woman who posed for illustrations of Gillis' girlfriend was included in the 90-minute [[PBS]] ''[[American Masters]]'' series film ''Norman Rockwell: Painting America''.{{cite web|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:WPIW&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0EB2C3E916F459CC&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Painting Life as He Wanted It to Be|accessdate=January 10, 2009|date=November 21, 1999|publisher=[[Newsbank]]|work=[[Washington Post]]|author=Brennan, Patricia}} The film coincided with the first comprehensive Rockwell touring exhibition, entitled ''Norman Rockwell: Pictures for the American People'', which was a seven-city tour.{{cite news|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A07EEDE173EF931A25755C0A9669C8B63&scp=2&sq=%22Four+Freedoms%22+Rockwell&st=nyt|title= This Week|accessdate=January 10, 2009|date=June 12, 2000|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Van Gelder, Lawrence}} {{dead link| date=June 2010 | bot=DASHBot}}{{cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/90208|title=Norman Rockwell Revisited|accessdate=January 10, 2009|date=November 15, 1999|publisher=Newsweek, Inc.|work=[[Newsweek magazine]]|author=Plagens, Peter}} The [[High Museum of Art]] and the [[Norman Rockwell Museum]] produced the exhibition that started at the High Museum on November 6, 1999, stopped at the [[Chicago Historical Society]], [[Corcoran Gallery of Art]], [[San Diego Museum of Art]], [[Phoenix Art Museum]], and Norman Rockwell Museum before concluding at the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]] on February 11, 2002.Hennessey and Knutson, pp. 94–102{{cite web|url=http://www.tfaoi.com/aa/1aa/1aa319.htm|title=Norman Rockwell: Pictures for the American People|accessdate=January 10, 2009|publisher=Traditional Fine Art Online, Inc/[[Chicago Historical Society]]}}{{cite news|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A07EEDE173EF931A25755C0A9669C8B63|title= This Week|accessdate=January 10, 2009|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Van Gelder, Lawrence | date=June 12, 2000}} After the official tour ended, his post covers were on display at the [[Florida International Museum]] from April 2002 until June 16, 2002.{{cite web|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:TTRB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0F306DA96A9FDD7B&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Americana Revisited|accessdate=January 10, 2009|date=April 18, 2002|publisher=[[Newsbank]]|work=[[The Tampa Tribune]]|author=Moncada, Carlos}} In September 2002, they were exhibited at the [[Eastern States Exposition]] in [[West Springfield, Massachusetts]].{{cite web|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:SUNB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0F63351095F2A969&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Rockwell's America|accessdate=January 10, 2009|date=September 12, 2002|publisher=[[Newsbank]]|work=[[Union-News]]|author=Gordon, Roni}} During the first 16 days of the fair, through Saturday September 28, the attendance was 1,052,511. From 2006 through 2010 Gillis appeared along with the ''Four Freedoms'' and ''Rosie The Riveter'' in a travelling exhibition entitled ''Norman Rockwell in the 1940s: A View of the American Homefront''. The 44-piece exhibition was organized by the Norman Rockwell Museum and made stops in places such as the [[Pensacola Museum of Art]] (April–July 2006),{{cite web|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:MBRB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=110DEA6B4AD67D88&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Arts Calendar|accessdate=January 10, 2009|date=April 9, 2006|publisher=[[Newsbank]]|work=[[Mobile Register]]}} [[Rogers Historical Museum]] (June–August 2007),{{cite web|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:SNLB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=119E98F61A2E4928&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Rockwell on display in Rogers, Arkansas|accessdate=January 10, 2009|date=June 18, 2007|publisher=[[Newsbank]]|work=[[Springfield News-Leader]]|author=Dale, Michael}} [[James A. Michener Art Museum]] (October 19, 2007 – February 10, 2008){{cite web|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:AMCB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=11B799A61D21B3E0&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Compelling culture ** Expansive exhibits, inventive premieres, edgy performances on the way|accessdate=January 10, 2009|date=September 2, 2007|publisher=[[Newsbank]]|work=[[The Morning Call]]|author=Gehman, Geoff}} and [[National Museum of the Marine Corps]] (September 28, 2009 – January 9, 2010).{{cite web|url=http://www.nrm.org/page65|title=Traveling Exhibitions|accessdate=January 10, 2009|date=January 10, 2009|publisher=Norman Rockwell Museum|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927023055/http://www.nrm.org/page65 |archivedate = September 27, 2007|deadurl=yes}} == Willie Gillis Series == Rockwell did not name his works, but many of them have one or two names by which they are known.
